column4: Checklist says MIXS:0000091 = _associated resource_ note whitespace in SCN. Agriculture says MIXS:0000091 = _url _. Neither found as names or synonyms at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes/

column14: or otherwise associated to the sequence.

column4: 11 packages say MIXS:0000018 = depth. Agriculture says _soil_depth_. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes acknowledges both terms
column12: The vertical distance below local surface
column13: e.g. for sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface
column14: respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

column4: Agriculture says MIXS:0001082 = _horizon_ and MIXS:0001291 = _soil_horizon_. Soil says MIXS:0001082 = _soil_horizon_. https://www.ncbi.nlmsoil_horizon.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes/ only acknowledges soil_horizon
column12: Specific layer in the land area which measures parallel to the soil surface and possesses physical characteristics which differ from the layers above and beneath
column14: [O horizon|A horizon|E horizon|B horizon|C horizon|R layer|Permafrost]

column4: 7 packages say MIXS:0001298. Only SymbiontAssociated and Agriculture use MIXS:0001309 (for any SCN)
column12: The taxonomic name of the organism(s) found living in mutualistic
column14: or parasitic symbiosis with the specific host. For cases when the specific host of the sample is a symbiont this field should refer to other organisms it is associated with. E.g.: hyperparasite species X (parasite of the parasite).
column15: symbionts of the symbiotic organism (host of the samples). e.g.: annotating a sample collected from a trematode with a nematomorpha cyst consider: species name of the nematomorph; {species name} or {common name}

column4: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes/ and symbiont-associated say sample_name. Checklist and 21 packages say samp_name.
column12: A local identifier or name that for the material sample used for extracting nucleic acids
column13: and subsequent sequencing. It can refer either to the original material collected or to any derived sub-samples. It can have any format
column14: but we suggest that you make it concise
column15: unique and consistent within your lab
column16: and as informative as possible. INSDC requires every sample name from a single Submitter to be unique. Use of a globally unique identifier for the field source_mat_id is recommended in addition to sample_name.

column4: 11 packages say MIXS:0000018 = depth. Agriculture says _soil_depth_. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes acknowledges both terms
column12: The vertical distance below local surface
column13: e.g. For sediment or soil samples depth is measured from sediment or soil surface
column14: respectively. Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.
column15: Depth can be reported as an interval for subsurface samples.

column4: Agriculture says MIXS:0001082 = _horizon_ and MIXS:0001291 = _soil_horizon_. Soil says MIXS:0001082 = _soil_horizon_. https://www.ncbi.nlmsoil_horizon.nih.gov/biosample/docs/attributes/ only acknowledges soil_horizon
column12: soil horizon is defined as the layer parallel to the soil surface whose physical
column13: chemical and biological characteristics differ from the layers above and beneath. Horizon can be described both in absolute terms (particle size distribution for texture
column14: for instance) and in terms relative to the surrounding material
column15: i.e. ‘coarser’ or ‘sandier’ than the horizons above and below.
column18: [O horizon|A horizon|E horizon|B horizon|C horizon|R layer|Permafrost]
